title: Joint Operations in San Luis Potosi
name: Joint Operations in San Luis Potosi
description: This data details each of the joint operations which took place in San Luis Potosi, Mexico from 09/15/2011 to 12/14/2011.

properties.event summary: 09/27/2011: On Tuesday, at kilometer marker 60 on Camino Nacional 57 Mexico-Piedras Negras, on the stretch of San Luis Potosi-Nunez, San Luis Potosi, Mexico, two individuals driving a white 2004 Freightliner with Veracruz license plate XR7497 pulling a 2009 Ferry flat bed with Federal Public Service license plate 586UM failed a gamma ray inspection at a security checkpoint. Federal police officers detained the two individuals after they found 115 packages of cocaine, weighing 125.355 kilograms in a hidden compartment in the tractor trailer. The vehicle was taken apart in search for drugs at the 12th Military Zone base. The detainees were identified as 45-year-old Felipe Martinez-Alvarez, "Cochi" and 21-year-old Jessica Contreras Enriquez. The two were travelling with a 10-month-old baby.
properties.event title: Federal Police Arrests Two People for Cocaine

properties.event summary: 10/01/2011 (Default Date): On Saturday, in Cardenas, San Luis Potosi, Mexico, in a joint operation by army personnel of the 12th Military Zone and State and Federal Police, Cardenas Chief of Police Juan Blanco Alvarado was arrested for allegedly collaborating with Los Zetas and Cisen.
properties.event title: Cardenas Chief of Police Arrested for Collaborating with Zetas and Cisen

properties.event summary: 11/04/2011: On Friday, in San Luis Potosi, Mexico, the Attorney General of the Republic (PGR) reported that military and state personnel incinerated the following: 572.758610 kilograms of marijuana, 53 marijuana plants, 150.685800 kilograms of cocaine, 212 psychotropic pills, and 1.966500 kilograms of peyote. Federal, State, and Municipal authorities in joint operations in the state of San Luis Potosi seized the drugs.
properties.division: Military, Federal, State and Municipal authorities
properties.event title: Attorney General of the Republic Incinerated Half a Ton of Marijuana in San Luis Potosi

properties.event summary: 11/30/2011: On Wednesday, in Colonia El Salitral, Villa de Reyes Municipality, San Luis Potosi, San Luis Potosi, Mexico, the Mexican army along with the Federal and State Police rescued three alleged kidnapping victims from a safe house used by an organized crime group. One of the women who was kidnapped was a minor. The group abandoned the safe house when they saw the military and fled in the direction of Santa Maria del Rio Municipality and escaped arrest. The kidnappers were allegedly young men from a gang travelling abroad a yellow Chevrolet Avalanche-type vehicle, a brown Suburban, and a black Ford Explorer-type vehicle.
properties.event title: Three Kidnapped Women Rescued from Safe House in San Luis Potosi

properties.event summary: 09/25/2011: On Sunday night at 2230, in Rio Verde, San Luis Potosi, Mexico, Mexican Army and Police personnel returned fire after being attacked by two militants at a nighttime check point at kilometer marker 30 on the Rio Verde-San Luis Potosi highway. Mexican Army personnel and Federal, State, and Municipal Police established the check point in response to civilian complaints. The gunmen in a Chevy compact vehicle attacked the checkpoint with various firearms. The authorities returned fire, causing the gunmen to lose control of their vehicle, flip the car and crash. Both of the gunmen were killed in the accident, and during the shootout, one of the police authorities was wounded. After the accident police found and seized four rifles, a metal box containing 210 bullets of various calibers, 10 magazines for various weapons, a tactical vest, two tactical cartridge belts, and the Chevy vehicle.
properties.event title: Military and Police Return Fire After Being Attacked at Checkpoint in

properties.event summary: 11/24/2011: On Thursday night in the streets of San Luis Potosi, San Luis Potosi, Mexico, four police officers were arrested in a joint operation by the Mexican army and Ministerial Police for the crime of extortion. Three of the officers were part of the Ministerial Police, identified as Arturo Serna Turrubiates, Diego Eduardo Macias Beltran, and Raul Alvizu Morales. The fourth officer was a State Policeman whose identity was not released.
properties.event title: Officers Arrested by Mexican Army for Extortion in San Luis Potosi
